author: Sarah Turner
title: The Gainsborough Bath Spa is just the place to splash out on a luxury break
text:
As I stepped over the threshold of the Gainsborough Hotel I found myself wondering – what would Jane think?
The novelist Jane Austen , that is, whose waspish presence – along with that of the Celts, Romans, Victorians and even the New Age travellers – hangs over the honey-stoned city of Bath.
I had feared that The Gainsborough, which only officially opened last week , might be marbled and mannered – especially as only a few journalists have been allowed through its door.
The first surprise is that the hotel has its own collection of Roman coins – part of the Beau Street Hoard – which was discovered during rebuilding work. More than that, it has one thing no other hotel in Britain has – its own source of piping hot thermal water.
A few rooms have baths with three taps rather than two – the last one being for your own private supply of mineral-enriched, centuries-old water, which comes out of the earth at a 46 degrees via a nearby borehole (thoughtfully, the hotel cools it a bit before it hits your bath).
Understated luxury: Room at the Gainsborough Hotel, Bath
But even if you don’t bag one of those rooms, there’s still the hotel spa. It’s reserved for guests for two hours in the morning and the evening – and if you book a treatment, you’ll get access to it between those times.
Tricked out with Romanesque columns and mosaics, there are a series of pools of different heats along with sauna, steam rooms, ice cave and central pool, with sun loungers – and a constant supply of hot chocolate.
“It’s our nod to the Georgians,” said one of the staff. I nodded approvingly. It’s not a stuffy hotel, there’s a West Country warmth here that seem to flow as easily as the spa water.
The Celts may have discovered Bath’s hot water springs around 100 BC, but it was the Romans who used them in buildings that allowed them to soak away the British winter in comfort.
Pretty city: River Avon and Pulteney Bridge in honey-stoned Bath
For £14 you can also visit the nearby Roman Baths ( romanbaths.co.uk ), which send you down below ground level to a series of bubbling springs in a complex of buildings only slightly less elaborate than the Gainsborough’s spa.
A millennium-and-a half later, the ­Georgians lapped it up as everyone who was anyone – including Jane Austen and family – came to Bath. After a major refurb it reopened in 2011.
I got my own experience of the waters with a Freedom treatment at the Gainsborough spa. Yes, dignity was left at the door but I soon became a convert as the therapist guided me in and under the water. Initially you feel vulnerable, then it’s utterly life-enhancing.
The Gainsborough is a collection of buildings that were a hospital, then a college. My friend Simon – who drank at its student bar – barely recognised it.
Euro nosh: Johann Lafer's restaurant
Now its 99 rooms are posh and serene, with dark walls, fabulously comfortable beds and glorious Georgian windows looking out at the city and into the hills.
There’s a bar where apothecary-style cocktails are dished up and a restaurant with delicious European food (the chef, Johann Lafer is German).
Yes, it’s expensive – cocktails come in at £16 a pop - but the three-course lunch is a bargain at £29.50 and steers clear of any hipster-style slate plates in favour of elegant porcelain.
All in all? Jane would definitely approve.
Travel File The deal: Rooms start at £285, room only, including a free mini-bar and access to the spa. www.thegainsboroughbathspa.co.uk 01225 358 888
Bath Spa for less: Bath Thermae Spa is just across the road and has two thermal pools over three floors including the rooftop pool – all heated to 33.5. A two-hour session starts at £32. Treatments are also available. There’s also the smaller Cross Bath at £18 for 90 minutes. www.thermaebathspa.com 0844 888 0844
Don't miss: Tea at the Georgian Pump Room, £21pp, booking recommended. www.romanbaths.co.uk
